instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is typically evaluated when assessing a new building technology?
output: Typically the energy performance of a baseline building is compared to the energy and life-cycle costs of alternatives to determine cost-effectiveness.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is a potential issue with choosing the lowest energy or life-cycle cost alternative?
output: The lowest energy or life-cycle cost alternative may not be the cleanest or lowest environmental impact.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: How can designers work towards a more sustainable design?
output: By calculating environmental impact designers can compare alternatives not only in terms of their energy performance but also their environmental performance.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: How are environmental impacts quantified in EnergyPlus?
output: Environmental impacts are quantified by modeling the amount of emissions using the input objects 'EnvironmentalImpactFactors' 'FuelFactors' and 'Output:EnvironmentalImpactFactors'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: How many different pollutants does EnergyPlus calculate?
output: EnergyPlus calculates the mass or volume of thirteen different pollutants.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What additional environmental factors does EnergyPlus consider aside from pollutants?
output: EnergyPlus also considers water consumed through evaporation in thermo- and hydro-electric generation and high- and low-level nuclear waste from nuclear electricity generation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: Where does much of the information for fossil fuel combustion come from?
output: Much of the information compiled for fossil fuel combustion comes from 'AP-42 Compilation of Air Pollutant Emission Factors'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: Where can more information on pollutants be found?
output: More information on pollutants can be found at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Clearinghouse for Inventories & Emission Factors.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What energy sources does EnergyPlus model?
output: EnergyPlus models energy performance of on-site fossil fuels and purchased electricity generated from various fuels including natural gas oil gasoline diesel coal hydroelectric nuclear wind solar power and biomass.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: How is energy performance converted in EnergyPlus?
output: The energy performance calculated by EnergyPlus is converted into a mass or volume of pollutants emitted.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What can be explored from a baseline building in EnergyPlus?
output: From a baseline building alternative energy and pollution-saving technologies can be explored and the energy savings and pollution reduction can be calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What do Figures in EnergyPlus illustrate?
output: Figures illustrate a comparison of two buildings simulated using Chicago weather data in EnergyPlus and the calculated pollutant levels based on U.S. national average pollutants.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: How is the mass or volume of each pollutant calculated in EnergyPlus?
output: The mass or volume of each pollutant is calculated by multiplying consumption by an emissions factor for each fuel.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What future feature is mentioned for emissions factors in EnergyPlus?
output: In future versions users will be able to schedule how the emissions factors change by time of day month season and year.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: How are emission factors adjusted for electricity in EnergyPlus?
output: For electricity the mix of generation fuel sources—whether utility state or regional—is used to adjust the emission factors.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What can users do if they have specific emissions factors for their building site and equipment?
output: Users can enter emissions factors specific to their building site and equipment directly into EnergyPlus.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: Are there default emissions factors in EnergyPlus?
output: There are no default emissions factors in EnergyPlus.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: How does the EPA categorize pollutants?
output: The EPA categorizes pollutants as either Criteria Pollutants or Hazardous Pollutants.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What are criteria pollutants according to the EPA?
output: Criteria pollutants are the six substances for which the EPA has set health-based standards including carbon monoxide (CO) nitrogen oxides (NOx) sulfur dioxide (SO2) particulate matter (PM10 and PM2.5) ozone (O3) and lead (Pb).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: How is ozone created according to the EPA?
output: Ozone is created in atmospheric photochemical reactions of volatile organic compounds ammonia and other substances.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is the purpose of the EnergyPlus model?
output: EnergyPlus models energy performance of on-site fossil fuels and purchased electricity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What fuels are included in the EnergyPlus model?
output: The model includes fuels such as natural gas oil gasoline diesel coal hydroelectric nuclear wind solar power and biomass.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus convert energy performance into pollutants?
output: The energy performance calculated by EnergyPlus is converted into a mass or volume of pollutants emitted.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What can be explored using a baseline building in EnergyPlus?
output: Alternative energy and pollution saving technologies can be explored and energy savings and pollution reduction can be calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What do Figures 341 and 342 illustrate?
output: They illustrate a comparison of two buildings simulated using Chicago weather data in EnergyPlus and the calculated pollutant levels.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: How is the mass or volume of each pollutant calculated?
output: Consumption is multiplied by an emissions factor for each fuel.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What future feature is mentioned for emissions factors?
output: Users will be able to schedule emissions factors by time of day month season and year.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: How is the mix of electricity generation fuel sources used?
output: It is used to adjust the emission factors.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What can users do if they have specific emissions factors?
output: Users can enter emissions factors specific to the building site and equipment directly.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: Are there any default emissions factors in EnergyPlus?
output: No there are no default emissions factors.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: How does the EPA categorize pollutants?
output: EPA categorizes pollutants as either Criteria Pollutants or Hazardous Pollutants.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What are Criteria Pollutants?
output: Criteria pollutants are the six substances for which EPA has set health-based standards.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: Why are ozone emissions not calculated in EnergyPlus?
output: Ozone is created in atmospheric photochemical reactions rather than direct building-related energy emissions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What ozone precursors are included in EnergyPlus?
output: Methane (CH\(_4\)) non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) and ammonia (NH\(_3\)) are included.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What are hazardous pollutants?
output: Hazardous pollutants are substances known or suspected to cause serious health problems such as cancer.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: Which hazardous substances associated with energy production are included?
output: Lead (Pb) and mercury (Hg) are included.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: Why is CO\(_2\) included in EnergyPlus?
output: CO\(_2\) is included because it is the largest greenhouse gas in terms of impact.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What is shown in Figure 341?
output: Figure 341 shows Example Annual Atmospheric Pollutants and Water Consumption.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What is shown in Figure 342?
output: Figure 342 shows Example Annual Total Carbon Equivalent for Major Greenhouse Gases.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What has the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change studied?
output: They have studied the effects on the relative radiative forcing effects of various greenhouse gases.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is Global Warming Potential (GWP)?
output: GWP is the effect described in terms of the Carbon Equivalent of a particular greenhouse gas.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is the Carbon Equivalent based on?
output: It is based on a factor of 1.0 for carbon.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: Which gases are included in the group of greenhouse gases?
output: The group includes carbon dioxide (CO\(_2\)) carbon monoxide nitrous oxide methane halocarbon emission hydrofluorocarbons (HFC) perfluorocarbons (PFC) and chlorofluorocarbons (CFC).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: Which gases are of main concern for building energy use?
output: The main gases of concern are carbon dioxide carbon monoxide methane and nitrous oxide.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is the impact of carbon monoxide emissions?
output: Despite its short life CO emissions may have a significant impact on climate forcing due to chemical impact on CH\(_4\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What pollutants are included in EnergyPlus instead of direct building-related energy emissions?
output: We include ozone precursors: methane (CH4) non-methane volatile organic compounds (NMVOC) and ammonia (NH3).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text

output: Hazardous pollutants are substances that are known or suspected to cause serious health problems such as cancer.

input: Which hazardous substances associated with energy production and use are included?
output: We include lead (Pb) and mercury (Hg).

output: CO2 is included because it is the largest greenhouse gas in terms of impact.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What has the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change studied regarding greenhouse gases?
output: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has studied the effects on the relative radiative forcing effects of various greenhouse gases.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is Global Warming Potential (GWP) described in terms of?
output: Global Warming Potential (GWP) is described in terms of the Carbon Equivalent of a particular greenhouse gas.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is the basis for the carbon equivalent?
output: The carbon equivalent is based on a factor of 1.0 for carbon.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: Which gases are included in the group of greenhouse gases studied?
output: This group of gases includes carbon dioxide (CO2) carbon monoxide nitrous oxide methane halocarbon emission hydrofluorocarbons (HFC) perfluorocarbons (PFC) and chlorofluorocarbons (CFC).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: Which gases are of main concern for building energy use?
output: The main gases of concern for building energy use are carbon dioxide carbon monoxide methane and nitrous oxide.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is the impact of carbon monoxide emissions on climate forcing?
output: CO emissions into the atmosphere may have a significant impact on climate forcing due to chemical impact on CH4 lifetime and tropospheric O3 and CO2 photochemical production.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is the carbon equivalent of carbon dioxide methane and nitrous oxide based on?
output: The carbon equivalent of carbon dioxide methane and nitrous oxide are calculated and then multiplied by their GWP on a 100-year time frame.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is the current status of data availability on nuclear waste from electricity generation?
output: Few utilities now provide data on nuclear waste resulting from electricity generation and no US national or state-level data are yet available (this will be added as data become available).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: Which utilities regularly report nuclear waste and in what terms?
output: Two Illinois utilities regularly report nuclear waste in terms of pounds per kWh or MWh for high-level waste and cubic feet per kWh or MWh for low-level waste.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What are the reported ranges for high-level and low-level nuclear waste?
output: For these two utilities high level nuclear waste values range from 0.0042 to 0.01 lb/MWh (7000 to 16000 g/MJ); low-level nuclear waste ranges from 0.0001 to 0.0002 ft³/MWh (0.01 to 0.02 m³/MJ) depending on relative proportion of nuclear as compared with other electricity generation sources.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is the responsibility of carbon dioxide (CO₂) according to UNEP 2002?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text
input: What is the interim method for estimating emission factors for countries with limited data?
output: An interim method is to compare the CO₂ emission factor for the country from IEA (2003) and match it to the state with the closest CO₂ emission factor in the table using the other emissions factors for that state.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Environmental Impacts -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What is a crucial component influencing climate change and urban microclimate?
output: Heat emissions from buildings are a crucial component influencing climate change and urban microclimate e.g. urban heat island effect.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What do the heat emissions from a building include?
output: The heat emissions from a building include heat releases from three levels of building systems: building envelope zone/space and HVAC systems.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: Why is quantifying heat emissions from buildings important?
output: Quantifying heat emissions from buildings and its spatiotemporal distribution have significant implications on urban environment and climate studies.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How can knowing the amount of heat released into the atmosphere help?
output: Knowing how much heat is released into the atmosphere can help quantify the magnitude of its impact on urban microclimate e.g. urban heat island effect and climate change.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What can the spatial and temporal distribution of heat emissions serve to do?
output: Spatial and temporal distribution of heat emissions can serve to locate hot spots in space and time therefore useful for prioritizing recourse to mitigate heat emissions from buildings.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What does this routine calculate and what is its scope?
output: This routine calculates heat emissions from buildings and the scope is restricted to report the buildings’ heat directly discharged to the ambient air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does the figure show regarding building heat emissions?
output: The figure shows the emissions include heat releases from three levels of building components: (1) building envelope - exterior surface convection and radiative heat transfer to the ambient air (2) zone - exhaust air or exfiltration to ambient (3) HVAC system - relief/exhaust air from AHUs and (4) HVAC system - heat rejected by air-cooled condensers or central plants including cooling towers of water-cooled chillers gas-fired boilers furnaces and water heaters.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What is excluded from the heat emissions calculation?
output: Any under-ground zone or envelope is excluded since heat from those spaces is rejected to ground instead of to ambient air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What is the caption of the figure?
output: Building released heat compositions

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What do the calculated heat emissions measure?
output: The calculated heat emissions measure the heat transfer from buildings to their ambient environment and can have both positive and negative values.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What do positive and negative heat emission values indicate?
output: The positive values indicate the building injects heat to the environment while the negative values indicate the building extracts heat from the environment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What types of heat emissions are calculated and reported for heat transfer via air flow?
output: For heat transfer via air flow both the sensible and latent heat emissions are calculated and reported.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emission from Building Envelope -> text
input: How do exterior surfaces emit heat to ambient air?
output: Exterior surfaces emit heat to ambient air in the form of convection and long-wave radiation which could be absorbed by particles and gas molecules in air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emission from Building Envelope -> text
input: What modifies the outside surface temperature through envelope conduction?
output: The internal sources modify the outside surface temperature through envelope conduction along with incident solar radiation which triggers the heat exchange with the ambient air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emission from Building Envelope -> text
input: What is not included in this part of the heat emission calculation?
output: This part does not include the long-wave radiation from surfaces to the sky or the ground.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emission from Building Envelope -> equation
input: What is the formula for calculating the surface outside face heat emission rate?
output: The surface outside face heat emission rate is calculated as: \(Q_emission surf = Q_conv surf + Hr * A * (T_surf - T_out)\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emission from Building Envelope -> text
input: What do the variables in the surface heat emission rate equation represent?
output: \(Q_conv surf\) is the surface outside face convection heat gain rate \(Hr\) is the surface outside face thermal radiation to air heat transfer coefficient \(A\) is the surface area \(T_surf\) and \(T_out\) are the surface and outdoor air temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emission from Zones -> text
input: How does discharge air carry heat to ambient at the zone level?
output: Discharge air carries heat to ambient at the zone level from exfiltration and exhaust fan.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emission from Zones -> text
input: What is exfiltration?
output: Exfiltration is unintended airflow to outside through envelope cracks as opposed to infiltration.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emission from Zones -> text
input: In which zones might exhaust fans be used for active venting?
output: Zones such as restroom kitchen and laundry room may be equipped with exhaust fans for active venting.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emission from Zones -> equation
input: How is the exfiltration heat emission from a zone calculated?
output: The exfiltration heat emission from a zone is calculated as: \(Q_exf zone = m_exf(h_zone - h_out)\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emission from Zones -> equation
input: How is the exhaust heat emission from a zone calculated?
output: The exhaust heat emission from a zone is calculated as: \(Q_exh zone = m_exh(h_zone - h_out)\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emission from Zones -> text
input: What do the variables in the zone heat emission equations represent?
output: \(m_exf\) is the exfiltration air mass flow rate \(m_exh\) is the zone exhaust air mass flow rate from the zone exhaust node \(h_zone\) and \(h_out\) are the zone and outdoor air enthalpy.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What do positive and negative values indicate about building heat transfer?
output: Positive values indicate the building injects heat to the environment while the negative values indicate the building extracts heat from the environment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What types of heat emissions are calculated and reported for heat transfer via air flow?
output: Both the sensible and latent heat emissions are calculated and reported.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How do exterior surfaces emit heat to ambient air?
output: Exterior surfaces emit heat to ambient air in the form of convection and long-wave radiation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What modifies the outside surface temperature through envelope conduction?
output: The internal sources modify the outside surface temperature through envelope conduction along with incident solar radiation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What is not included in the heat exchange with the ambient air?
output: This part does not include the long-wave radiation from surfaces to the sky or the ground.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> equation
input: What is the equation for the surface outside face heat emission rate?
output: \\( Q_emission surf = Q_conv surf + Hr * A * (T_surf - T_out) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What do the variables in the heat emission rate equation represent?
output: \\(Q_conv surf\\) is the surface outside face convection heat gain rate \\(Hr\\) is the surface outside face thermal radiation to air heat transfer coefficient \\(A\\) is the surface area \\(T_surf\\) and \\(T_out\\) are the surface and outdoor air temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How does discharge air carry heat to ambient at the zone level?
output: Discharge air carries heat to ambient at the zone level from exfiltration and exhaust fan.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What is exfiltration?
output: Exfiltration is unintended airflow to outside through envelope cracks as opposite to infiltration.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: Which zones may be equipped with exhaust fans for active venting?
output: Zones such as restroom kitchen and laundry room may be equipped with exhaust fans for active venting.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> equation
input: What is the equation for the exfiltration heat emission rate at the zone level?
output: \\( Q_exf zone = m_exf(h_zone - h_out) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> equation
input: What is the equation for the exhaust heat emission rate at the zone level?
output: \\( Q_exh zone = m_exh(h_zone - h_out) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What do the variables in the zone heat emission equations represent?
output: \\(m_exf\\) is the exfiltration air mass flow rate \\(m_exh\\) is the zone exhaust air mass flow rate from the zone exhaust node \\(h_zone\\) and \\(h_out\\) are the zone and outdoor air enthalpy.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> equation
input: What is the equation for the sensible exfiltration heat emission rate at the zone level?
output: \\( Q_exf zone sensible = m_exf * c * (T_zone - T_out) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> equation
input: What is the equation for the sensible exhaust heat emission rate at the zone level?
output: \\( Q_exh zone sensible = m_exh * c * (T_zone - T_out) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What does the variable \\(c\\) represent in the sensible heat emission equations?
output: \\(c\\) is the specific heat of air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How are the latent parts of heat emission determined?
output: The latent parts are determined by taking the difference between the total and the sensible rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How is the exfiltration rate for each zone calculated?
output: For each zone its exfiltration rate is calculated by solving a mass flow balance on the zone including infiltration ventilation outdoor air mixing zone-to-zone mixing and all of the zone inlet exhaust and return nodes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What does this part of zone exhaust only include?
output: This part of zone exhaust only includes the exhaust heat at the zone level defined by \\textbfFan:ZoneExhaust or \\textbfAirflowNetwork:MultiZone:Component:ZoneExhaustFan.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How is the exhaust heat from Zone HVAC system nodes handled?
output: The exhaust heat from Zone HVAC system nodes is included in the next item.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How do HVAC systems relieve heat from system outdoor air relief nodes?
output: HVAC systems relieve heat from system outdoor air relief nodes and the total and sensible emission rate are calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> equation
input: What is the equation for the exhaust heat emission rate from HVAC systems?
output: \\( Q_exh sys = m_exh(h_node - h_out) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> equation
input: What is the equation for the sensible exhaust heat emission rate from HVAC systems?
output: \\( Q_exh sys sensible = m_exh * c * (T_node - T_out) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How is the air exchange with outdoor represented in HVAC systems?
output: The air exchange with outdoor is represented with an \\textbfOutdoorAir:Mixer object in the \\textbfAirLoopHVAC:OutdoorAirSystem object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How is the air exchange with outdoor aggregated and reported?
output: This part is aggregated and reported by each \\textbfController:OutdoorAir object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How does HVAC system equipment exchange heat with ambient air?
output: HVAC system equipment also directly exchanges heat with ambient air via refrigeration cycle and its energy usage.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What happens to waste heat from gas-fired boilers/heaters?
output: For gas-fired boilers/heaters waste heat is exhausted to outside together with combustion byproduct.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What happens to heat during space cooling?
output: For space cooling heat is removed from indoors.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> equation
input: What is the equation for the sensible heat emission from zone exfiltration?
output: Q_exf zone sensible = m_exf * c * (T_zone - T_out)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> equation
input: What is the equation for the sensible heat emission from zone exhaust?
output: Q_exh zone sensible = m_exh * c * (T_zone - T_out)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What is the specific heat of air and what do \(T_zone\) and \(T_out\) represent?
output: The specific heat of air is denoted by \(c\) and \(T_zone\) and \(T_out\) represent the zone and outdoor air temperatures respectively.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How are the latent parts of heat emissions determined?
output: The latent parts are determined by taking the difference between the total and the sensible rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How is the exfiltration rate for each zone calculated?
output: The exfiltration rate for each zone is calculated by solving a mass flow balance on the zone including infiltration ventilation outdoor air mixing zone-to-zone mixing and all of the zone inlet exhaust and return nodes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What does the zone exhaust include?
output: This part of zone exhaust only includes the exhaust heat at the zone level defined by Fan:ZoneExhaust or AirflowNetwork:MultiZone:Component:ZoneExhaustFan.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How is the exhaust heat aggregated for each zone?
output: For each zone the exhaust heat is aggregated by searching its exhaust fans.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: Where is the exhaust heat from Zone HVAC system nodes included?
output: The exhaust heat from Zone HVAC system nodes is included in the next item.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How do HVAC systems relieve heat from system outdoor air relief nodes?
output: HVAC systems relieve heat from system outdoor air relief nodes and the total and sensible emission rate are calculated using specific equations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> equation
input: What is the equation for the total heat emission from HVAC system relief air?
output: Q_exh sys = m_exh(h_node - h_out)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> equation
input: What is the equation for the sensible heat emission from HVAC system relief air?
output: Q_exh sys sensible = m_exh * c * (T_node - T_out)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How is the latent part of the heat emission from HVAC system relief air determined?
output: The latent parts are determined by taking the difference between the total and sensible rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What object represents the air exchange with outdoor in the HVAC system?
output: The air exchange with outdoor is represented with an OutdoorAir:Mixer object in the AirLoopHVAC:OutdoorAirSystem object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How is the part of heat emission from HVAC systems aggregated and reported?
output: This part is aggregated and reported by each Controller:OutdoorAir object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How does HVAC system equipment directly exchange heat with ambient air?
output: HVAC system equipment directly exchanges heat with ambient air via the refrigeration cycle and its energy usage.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What happens to waste heat in gas-fired boilers/heaters?
output: In gas-fired boilers/heaters waste heat is exhausted to the outside together with combustion byproducts.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What occurs during space cooling regarding heat removal?
output: During space cooling heat is removed from indoors and dumped to outdoor at the condenser side or corresponding cooling equipment such as a cooling tower.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How does energy consumed by outdoor equipment dissipate?
output: Energy consumed by outdoor equipment will directly dissipate to the ambient air such as compressors and fans in packaged DX systems.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How is the surface outside face heat emission rate calculated for gas-powered combustion units?
output: For gas-powered combustion units the surface outside face heat emission rate is calculated as Fuel generated heat - fuel heat supply.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What are the methods for calculating the heat emission rate for air-cooled condensing units?
output: For air-cooled condensing units the heat emission rate is calculated as the cooling rate plus the electric power of the condenser fan and compressor.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What are the methods for calculating the heat emission rate for water-cooled condensing units?
output: For water-cooled condensing units the heat emission rate is calculated as the total heat transfer rate with outdoor air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How does the calculation of HVAC rejected heat vary?
output: The detailed calculation of HVAC rejected heat varies with different HVAC object groups and component types.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table
input: What is summarized in Table 94?
output: Table 94 summarizes the heat rejection calculation for different HVAC component types.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the calculation method for chilled water cooling coils in the Coils object group?
output: The calculation method for chilled water cooling coils is to emit heat in the condensing unit defined in Condenser Equipment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the calculation method for fuel-heated heating coils in the Coils object group?
output: The calculation method for fuel-heated heating coils is Fuel Consumed + Heating Coil Defrost Electric Consumption + Heating Coil Crankcase Heater Electric Consumption – Heating Coil Total Heating Energy.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the calculation method for hot water/steam heating coils in the Coils object group?
output: The calculation method for hot water/steam heating coils is to emit heat in the plant source defined in Plant Heating and Cooling Equipment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the calculation method for air-cooled DX cooling coils in the Coils object group?
output: The calculation method for air-cooled DX cooling coils is Cooling Coil Source Side Heat Transfer Rate + Cooling Coil Electric Power + Cooling Coil Crankcase Heater Electric Energy + Fuel Waste Heat.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the calculation method for evaporatively-cooled DX cooling coils in the Coils object group?
output: The calculation method for evaporatively-cooled DX cooling coils is Evaporative Cooler Condenser Pump Electricity Consumption + Cooling Coil Basin Heater Electric Energy + Evaporative Cooler Water Volume * rho * evaporation heat of water (\\(\\delta H_we\\)).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: Where is the heat dumped in a cooling system?
output: The heat is dumped to outdoor at the condenser side or corresponding cooling equipment such as cooling tower.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How does energy consumed by outdoor equipment dissipate?
output: Energy consumed by outdoor equipment will directly dissipate to the ambient air such as compressors and fans in packaged DX systems.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: How is the surface outside face heat emission rate calculated for a gas-powered combustion unit?
output: The surface outside face heat emission rate is calculated as Fuel generated heat - fuel heat supply for a gas-powered combustion unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What is the calculation method for an air-cooled condensing unit?
output: The calculation method for an air-cooled condensing unit is cooling rate + electric power of condenser fan and compressor.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What is the calculation method for a water-cooled condensing unit?
output: The calculation method for a water-cooled condensing unit is the total heat transfer rate with outdoor air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> text
input: What does Table 94 summarize?
output: Table 94 summarizes the detailed calculation of HVAC rejected heat which varies with different HVAC object groups and component types.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the title of the table summarizing heat rejection calculations?
output: The title of the table is 'Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the heat emission calculation method for a chilled water cooling coil?
output: The heat emission calculation method for a chilled water cooling coil is 'Emit heat in condensing unit defined in Condenser Equipment'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: How is the heat emission calculated for a heating coil (fuel heated)?
output: The heat emission for a heating coil (fuel heated) is calculated as 'Fuel Consumed + Heating Coil Defrost Electric Consumption + Heating Coil Crankcase Heater Electric Consumption – Heating Coil Total Heating Energy'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the heat emission calculation method for a hot water/steam heating coil?
output: The heat emission calculation method for a hot water/steam heating coil is 'Emit heat in plant source defined in Plant Heating and Cooling Equipment'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: How is the heat emission calculated for a DX cooling coil (air-cooled)?
output: The heat emission for a DX cooling coil (air-cooled) is calculated as 'Cooling Coil Source Side Heat Transfer Rate + Cooling Coil Electric Power + Cooling Coil Crankcase Heater Electric Energy + Fuel Waste Heat'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the heat emission calculation method for a DX cooling coil (Evaporatively-cooled)?
output: The heat emission calculation method for a DX cooling coil (Evaporatively-cooled) is 'Evaporative Cooler Condenser Pump Electricity Consumption + Cooling Coil Basin Heater Electric Energy + Evaporative Cooler Water Volume * rho * evaporation heat of water (δHwe)'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the heat emission calculation method for a DX VRF cooling coil?
output: The heat emission calculation method for a DX VRF cooling coil is 'Emit heat in condensing unit defined in Variable Refrigerant Flow Equipment'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: How is the heat emission calculated for a DX heating coil (air-cooled)?
output: The heat emission for a DX heating coil (air-cooled) is calculated as 'Heating Coil Electric Power / Fuel Consumed + Heating Coil Defrost Electric Power + Heating Coil Crankcase Heater Electric Power – Heating Coil Total Heating Rate'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the heat emission calculation method for a water to air heat pump?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: How is the heat emission calculated for a DX VRF cooling/heating coil?
output: The heat emission for a DX VRF cooling/heating coil is calculated as 'Emit heat in condensing unit defined in Variable Refrigerant Flow Equipment'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the heat emission calculation method for evaporative coolers?
output: The heat emission calculation method for evaporative coolers is 'Evaporative Cooler Condenser Pump Electricity Consumption + Cooling Coil Basin Heater Electric Energy + Evaporative Cooler Water Volume * rho * evaporation heat of water (δHwe)'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: How is the heat emission calculated for a VRF air-to-air heat pump condensing unit (air-cooled)?
output:
The heat emission for a VRF air-to-air heat pump condensing unit (air-cooled) is calculated as 'VRF Heat Pump Total Cooling Rate + VRF Heat Pump Total Electric Power (cooling mode)
VRF Heat Pump Total Heating Electric Power / Fuel Rate - VRF Heat Pump Total Heating Rate (heating mode)'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: What is the heat emission calculation method for a VRF air-to-air heat pump condensing unit (evaporative-cooled)?
output: The heat emission calculation method for a VRF air-to-air heat pump condensing unit (evaporative-cooled) is 'Evaporative Cooler Condenser Pump Electricity Consumption + Cooling Coil Basin Heater Electric Energy + Evaporative Cooler Water Volume * rho * evaporation heat of water (δHwe)'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types
input: How is the heat emission calculated for a VRF air-to-air heat pump condensing unit (water-cooled)?
output: The heat emission for a VRF air-to-air heat pump condensing unit (water-cooled) is calculated as 'VRF Heat Pump Condenser Heat Transfer Rate'.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Heat Emissions -> table row: Heat Rejection Calculation for Different HVAC Component Types

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Thermal Resilience -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What was the basis for the heat index computation before version 25.1?
output: Before version 25.1 the computation of the heat index was a refinement of a result obtained by multiple regression analysis carried out by Lans P. Rothfusz and described in a 1990 National Weather Service (NWS) Technical Attachment (SR 90-23).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: On what temperature scale is the heat index calculation based?
output: The calculation is based on degree Fahrenheit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> equation
input: What is the regression equation of Rothfusz for calculating the heat index?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What do the variables in the Rothfusz regression equation represent?
output: HI = heat index (expressed as an apparent temperature in degrees Fahrenheit) T = ambient dry-bulb temperature (in degrees Fahrenheit) R = relative humidity (percentage value between 0 and 100) c_1 = -42.379 c_2 = 2.04901523 c_3 = 10.14333127 c_4 = -0.22475541 c_5 = -0.00683783 c_6 = -0.05481717 c_7 = 0.00122874 c_8 = 0.00085282 c_9 = -0.00000199.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> equation
input: What adjustment is subtracted from HI if the RH is less than 13% and the temperature is between 80 and 112°F?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> equation
input: What adjustment is added to HI if the RH is greater than 85% and the temperature is between 80 and 87°F?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: When is the Rothfusz regression not appropriate?
output: The Rothfusz regression is not appropriate when conditions of temperature and humidity warrant a heat index value below about 80°F.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> equation
input: What is the simpler formula applied when the Rothfusz regression is not appropriate?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What is the procedure if the simple formula results in a heat index value of 80°F or higher?
output: If this heat index value is 80°F or higher the full regression equation along with any adjustment as described above is applied.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: For what conditions is the Rothfusz regression not valid?
output: The Rothfusz regression is not valid for extreme temperature and relative humidity conditions beyond the range of data considered by Steadman.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What change was made in version 25.1 regarding the heat index calculation?
output: Starting from version 25.1 the heat index calculation allows the use of the extended heat index method developed by Lu & Romps.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What happens if the 'Algorithm' field of HeatIndexAlgorithm is set to 'Extended'?
output: By selecting 'Extended' in the 'Algorithm' field of HeatIndexAlgorithm the extended heat index will be used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What method is used if the 'Algorithm' field is 'Simplified' or left empty?
output: If the field is 'Simplified' or left empty the Rothfusz-Steadman method described above will be used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What issue can arise with the heat index calculated using the Rothfusz-Steadman method?
output: The heat index calculated with the Rothfusz-Steadman method can give unrealistic results for very hot and humid or very cold and dry conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What is the advantage of the extended index developed by Lu & Romps?
output: The extended index extends the domain of the heat index calculation to all combinations of temperature and relative humidity and gives a more realistic heat index for the extreme conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What is the basis for the implementation of the extended index in EnergyPlus?
output: The implementation in EnergyPlus is based on the released Python code by Lu and Romps.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What metrics are reported under the Annual Thermal Resilience Report?
output: The Heat Index Hours (accumulated hours for a space) and Heat Index OccupantHours (accumulated hours for the sum of all occupants in a space) of each level for each zone and the whole building are reported under the Annual Thermal Resilience Report.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What is the Standard Effective Temperature (SET)?
output: Standard Effective Temperature (SET) is a model of human response to the thermal environment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: Who developed the Standard Effective Temperature (SET) model?
output: The SET model was developed by A.P. Gagge.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: When was the SET model accepted by ASHRAE?
output: The SET model was accepted by ASHRAE in 1986.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What is another name for the SET model?
output: The SET model is also referred to as the Pierce Two-Node model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: How is the calculation of SET similar to PMV?
output: Its calculation is similar to PMV because it is a comprehensive comfort index based on heat-balance equations that incorporate personal factors of clothing and metabolic rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What is the fundamental difference of the SET model compared to PMV?
output: Its fundamental difference is it takes a two-node method to represent human physiology in measuring skin temperature and skin wettedness.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: How does ASHRAE 55-2010 define SET?
output: ASHRAE 55-2010 defines SET as 'the temperature of an imaginary environment at 50% relative humidity < 0.1 m/s [0.33 ft/s] average air speed and mean radiant temperature equal to average air temperature in which total heat loss from the skin of an individual is the same as in the actual environment.'

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
input: What does the variable T_dew represent in the Humidex formula?
output: In the Humidex formula T_dew represents the dew-point temperature in Celsius.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: None -> Section: Resilience Metrics -> text
